user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_CallOnce:
```c
void UT_Stub_CallOnce(void (*Func)(void))
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *OnceEnt;
    UT_EntryKey_t        FuncKey;
    int32                i;

    if (Func == NULL)
    {
        return;
    }

    FuncKey = (UT_EntryKey_t)Func;
    OnceEnt = NULL;
    StubPtr = UT_StubTable;
    for (i = 0; i < UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS; ++i)
    {
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED && OnceEnt == NULL)
        {
            OnceEnt = StubPtr;
        }
        else if (StubPtr->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE && StubPtr->FuncKey == FuncKey)
        {
            OnceEnt = StubPtr;
            break;
        }
        ++StubPtr;
    }

    if (OnceEnt == NULL)
    {
        /* should never happen -- UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS needs increase if it does */
        UtAssert_Abort("Cannot do CallOnce - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
    }
    else if (OnceEnt->EntryType == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        OnceEnt->EntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_CALL_ONCE;
        OnceEnt->FuncKey   = FuncKey;

        Func();
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_CallOnce:
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}}
...
#define UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS 200
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment modifies the function-parameter 'Func' (the pointer itself). The uses of 'Func' are: a NULL check (if (Func == NULL)), a cast to an integer key (FuncKey = (UT_EntryKey_t)Func), and an invocation (Func()). None of these assign to or otherwise alter the pointer parameter (there is no 'Func = ...', no increment/decrement, no taking of its address for modification). Local variables and the UT_StubTable entries are modified, but those are distinct objects and do not constitute modification of the parameter itself. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided function.
